AR — The Future? (not just for Coding)
<http://www.croquet.zone/2019/01/why-ar-will-win-and-why-it-matters-how.html?m=1|http://www.croquet.zone/2019/01/why-ar-will-win-and-why-it-matters-how.html?m=1>

attachments.title: Why AR Will Win -  And Why it Matters How it Will Win
attachments.text: The continued effort to enable the augmented conversation.
attachments.fallback: Why AR Will Win -  And Why it Matters How it Will Win

elements.text: AR — The Future? (not just for Coding)
http://www.croquet.zone/2019/01/why-ar-will-win-and-why-it-matters-how.html?m=1

text:
Interesting.  A good read.  Especially since many of the claims shock and surprise.

For instance, "That sounds like a wonderful world,"  where the that sounds like HYPER-REALITY <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YJg02ivYzSs>.

OR

"AR and VR have pointing rods with almost no haptic feedback at all aside from perhaps vibrating. It has none of the compelling qualities of the phone interface and is not even particularly good at gross manipulation."  How is a tiny tap surface ideal?  Sure wands aren't the best, but hand tracking is nearly available.

OR

"Most people do not remember taking their phone out to use it.  [I'm not sure Mr. Smith caries a handbag.]  It just magically appears in their hands and takes over their focus. [Is this supposed to be good?]  You never think about using the phone when you are using the phone – you see through it to the rich world on the other side of the screen."  Is Mr. Smith trolling us or has he mastered his phone in a way that I have not.  Some of my interactions are super smooth but a lot remain clunky.

"And it is going to be glorious – and terrible"  does ask us to put on our critical glasses.

attachments.title: HYPER-REALITY
attachments.video_html: <iframe width="400" height="225" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/YJg02ivYzSs?feature=oembed&autoplay=1&iv_load_policy=3" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Interesting.  A good read.  Especially since many of the claims shock and surprise.

For instance, "That sounds like a wonderful world,"  where the that sounds like HYPER-REALITY

.

OR

"AR and VR have pointing rods with almost no haptic feedback at all aside from perhaps vibrating. It has none of the compelling qualities of the phone interface and is not even particularly good at gross manipulation."  How is a tiny tap surface ideal?  Sure wands aren't the best, but hand tracking is nearly available.

OR

"Most people do not remember taking their phone out to use it.  [I'm not sure Mr. Smith caries a handbag.]  It just magically appears in their hands and takes over their focus. [Is this supposed to be good?]  You never think about using the phone when you are using the phone – you see through it to the rich world on the other side of the screen."  Is Mr. Smith trolling us or has he mastered his phone in a way that I have not.  Some of my interactions are super smooth but a lot remain clunky.

"And it is going to be glorious – and terrible"  does ask us to put on our critical glasses.

text: What I do know is...

elements.text: What I do know is...

text:
1. The best feature of my Apple Watch is how it makes me not have to pick up my phone.
2. AR and VR are really, really different for me.  Whereas VR is meant to be immersive, AR is better the lighter and more contextual.
3. Interruption is an instance of disregarding context.

elements.text: The best feature of my Apple Watch is how it makes me not have to pick up my phone.
AR and VR are really, really different for me.  Whereas VR is meant to be immersive, AR is better the lighter and more contextual.
Interruption is an instance of disregarding context.

text: Bubbling.  Dynamicland's most important feature is the shared context.

elements.text: Bubbling.  Dynamicland's most important feature is the shared context.

text: A story.  I read at the dinner table: to my five year old, to my wife.  For Christmas, we listened to Patrick Stewart read A Christmas Carol.  Even with pause an arm's reach away listening to the recording was noticeably more clunky than ease of pauses, restarts, volume changes that live reading affords.

elements.text: A story.  I read at the dinner table: to my five year old, to my wife.  For Christmas, we listened to Patrick Stewart read A Christmas Carol.  Even with pause an arm's reach away listening to the recording was noticeably more clunky than ease of pauses, restarts, volume changes that live reading affords.

text:
While we’re at it: VR — What went wrong
<https://twitter.com/unconed/status/1215977903629971456|https://twitter.com/unconed/status/1215977903629971456>

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/unconed|@unconed>: The BBC asks "What went wrong with virtual reality?"

"Too expensive, too solitary, too costly." But nobody ever talks about the most obvious one, and that's because our culture still doesn't understand gaming as a medium. Especially not the press. 🧵
attachments.text:
The BBC asks "What went wrong with virtual reality?"

"Too expensive, too solitary, too costly." But nobody ever talks about the most obvious one, and that's because our culture still doesn't understand gaming as a medium. Especially not the press. 🧵

elements.text: While we’re at it: VR — What went wrong
https://twitter.com/unconed/status/1215977903629971456

text: Some excellent points by Wittens on why VR is failing to catch on at present. I agree that VR will take a very long time get right, and the Pokemon Go success indicates to me that AR will outsell VR.

elements.text: Some excellent points by Wittens on why VR is failing to catch on at present. I agree that VR will take a very long time get right, and the Pokemon Go success indicates to me that AR will outsell VR.

text: VR seems to be in its Commodore 64 phase.  Some is amazing, a lot is clunky.  What is actually makes for good and bad experiences ends up being different from what one might expect.

elements.text: VR seems to be in its Commodore 64 phase.  Some is amazing, a lot is clunky.  What is actually makes for good and bad experiences ends up being different from what one might expect.

text: So VR hasn't failed

elements.text: So VR hasn't failed

text: I think this is a common "truth" among a certain set of tech people\early adopters

elements.text: I think this is a common "truth" among a certain set of tech people\early adopters

text: but there has been steady growth in the market

elements.text: but there has been steady growth in the market

text: there's also a set of people that remember VR in the 90s or earlier that claim VR will not succeed because it didn't succeed now, but they're entirely not worth listening to :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: there's also a set of people that remember VR in the 90s or earlier that claim VR will not succeed because it didn't succeed now, but they're entirely not worth listening to

text: its like saying smartphones never should have succeeded because Newton and General Magic didn't work out

elements.text: its like saying smartphones never should have succeeded because Newton and General Magic didn't work out

text: the problem with AR is that it's a significantly harder technical challenge to build a useful AR device than it is to build a useful VR device

elements.text: the problem with AR is that it's a significantly harder technical challenge to build a useful AR device than it is to build a useful VR device

text: so I agree, VR will probably never be a PC or smartphone sized market

elements.text: so I agree, VR will probably never be a PC or smartphone sized market

text: which is the metric a lot of people are using for success

elements.text: which is the metric a lot of people are using for success

text: but I think it will be a game console sized market

elements.text: but I think it will be a game console sized market

text: the AR device that "wins" is also further off than people think it is

elements.text: the AR device that "wins" is also further off than people think it is

text: and there is also a possibility that something that looks closer to a VR device still wins, especially if it has good enough pass through

elements.text: and there is also a possibility that something that looks closer to a VR device still wins, especially if it has good enough pass through

text: for productivity, gaming and media I think VR or VR with passthrough is probably as good a better than a good AR device

elements.text: for productivity, gaming and media I think VR or VR with passthrough is probably as good a better than a good AR device

text: that device looks more like a PC than a smartphone in terms of use though

elements.text: that device looks more like a PC than a smartphone in terms of use though

text: and market size

elements.text: and market size

text: the simple metric is that Oculus Quest, or even Valve Index, is much closer to a viable successful consumer product than Magic Leap or Hololens 2

elements.text: the simple metric is that Oculus Quest, or even Valve Index, is much closer to a viable successful consumer product than Magic Leap or Hololens 2
